body.p: Which of the following could be the 95% confidence interval for p, based on the same data?

multiple_choice.choice: Both the third and fourth intervals could be the 95% interval for p.

response.feedback: Incorrect. Note that since the p-value of the test was .001, Ho was rejected (at the .05 significance level, or an even lower level). This means that the 95% confidence interval for p cannot include .605 as a plausible value.

Incorrect. Note that since the p-value of the test was .001, Ho was rejected (at the .05 significance level, or an even lower level). This means that the 95% confidence interval for p cannot include .605 as a plausible value.

Incorrect. Note that since the p-value of the test was .001, Ho was rejected (at the .05 significance level, or an even lower level). This means that the 95% confidence interval for p cannot include .605 as a plausible value. While it true that, therefore, this could be a confidence interval for p (since it does not include .605), it is not the only plausible confidence interval.

Incorrect. Note that, since the p-value of the test was .001, Ho was rejected (at the .05 significance level, or an even lower level). This means that the 95% confidence interval for p cannot include .605 as a plausible value. While it true that, therefore, this could be a confidence interval for p (since it does not include .605), it is not the only plausible confidence interval.

Good job! Indeed, since the p-value of the test was .001, Ho was rejected (at the .05 significance level, or an even lower level). This means that the 95% confidence interval for p cannot include .605 as a plausible value, which both the third and fourth confidence intervals satisfy. Comment: The third confidence interval is the actual one that was found in the follow-up study.
